b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:23): often I don't disagree about what the ideal world would be but I disagree about making designs that require an ideal world. designs that work in a world where people don't behave in ideal ways are more robust

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:39): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - very true about not designing for an ideal world. I can say in my professional experience it is plain folly to design systems with the "But no real user is ever going to do X", where you X is something you would never do yourself and so assume no user would ever be likely to try.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:39): Because some user will eventually do it, of course.

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:41): At that point you can blame the idiot user all you want, or, say, explain as much as you want to the client/customer for whom you built that system that you had no way of predicting that a user would ever try that...
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:42): I'd like to see some of the people advocating that approach try to explain it to real customers.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:42): "Well, we designed it that way because we didn't want to encourage people to be lazy."
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:43): back when I was doing my military service, I was tasked with the maintenance and UI implementation of a metadata spec
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:43): I got involved in the project too late and didn't have enough rank to turn the spec around
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:44): the attitude was that the military can require any metadata they please because they can order people into compliance
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:44): order the sun to stop shining
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:45): making people to provide additional data that they don't want to provide doesn't work even in the military
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:45): people will find ways to route around systems that ask for stuff they don't want to provide
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (12:46): the alt tag isn't only data people don't want to provide, 9/10 it's data you can't provide
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (12:46): the phrase "a picture is worth a thousand words" springs to mind

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:47): (I won't go into details)

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:47): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - yeah, when my dad first joined the Air Force during the 1960s, he was on one of the ICBM missile crews, stationed in bunkers in Nebraska, and said that part of their hourly duties were in providing information on forms/checklists about all the stuff they were supposed to check each hour
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:48): most of which if they actually did it would have taken 2 hours to do
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:48): some of which was not even possible to do at all under the conditions
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:49): he said they "complied by sharpened pencil", or something in those terms
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:49): said they kept plenty of sharp pencils around
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:49): to fill out all the checklists
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:50): without ever completing half of the tasks they were supposedly checking off as having been performed
